problems.title: Risk Data Aggregation and Quality Failures Hindering BCBS 239 Compliance
problems.description: Financial institutions worldwide face persistent challenges in aggregating risk data accurately and efficiently, resulting in widespread non-compliance with BCBS 239 principles established over a decade ago. Currently, only 2 out of 31 global systemically important banks (G-SIBs) fully comply with all principles, with six of the eleven principles showing regression or stalled implementation. The root causes include fragmented legacy systems, data silos across departments, inconsistent data definitions, manual processes, and lack of clear ownership and accountability at the board level. The ECB has made remediation of deficiencies in risk data aggregation and reporting a top supervisory priority for 2025-2027, with increasing penalties for non-compliance. Banks struggle with scattered data across dozens or hundreds of siloed systems, inadequate data governance, and the inability to generate timely risk reports. This creates systemic risks as institutions cannot accurately assess their aggregate risk exposures during stress events, potentially leading to cascading failures across the financial system.

problems.title: AI and Machine Learning Model Risk Validation Challenges in Capital Markets
problems.description: The rapid adoption of artificial intelligence and machine learning models for risk management, trading, and credit decisions in capital markets has outpaced the development of robust validation frameworks. Risk managers face the dual challenge of harnessing AI's benefits while mitigating its unique and evolving risks. Key challenges include model explainability (the 'black box' problem), dynamic model behavior that changes over time, data drift detection, bias identification, and maintaining human oversight. Traditional model validation approaches designed for parametric models are inadequate for complex neural networks and ensemble methods. Regulators are increasingly focused on AI governance, requiring comprehensive frameworks that many institutions lack. The integration of AI/ML into low-latency trading systems presents additional challenges, as ML models typically introduce latency unacceptable in high-frequency trading environments. Organizations must develop AI governance structures that balance innovation with risk control, addressing concerns about model stability, adversarial attacks, and the potential for AI-amplified systemic risks.

problems.title: Climate Risk Stress Testing Methodological Limitations and Data Gaps
problems.description: Financial institutions face significant challenges in developing robust climate risk stress testing methodologies, representing one of the most complex systemic risks facing the financial system. Climate change presents multi-faceted challenges that require understanding across physical risks (extreme weather, sea level rise), transition risks (policy changes, technology shifts), and liability risks. Current stress testing approaches suffer from fundamental limitations including inadequate climate scenario modeling, lack of granular asset-level climate exposure data, difficulty modeling non-linear tipping points and feedback effects, and challenges in translating climate impacts to financial metrics over appropriate time horizons. Regulatory frameworks continue to evolve with requirements from the ECB, Bank of England, and other supervisors, but methodological standards remain inconsistent. Banks struggle to integrate climate scenarios into existing risk frameworks designed for shorter time horizons. The complexity of modeling second and third-order effects, such as supply chain disruptions and migration patterns, further complicates accurate risk assessment.

problems.title: Real-Time Risk Monitoring Latency Constraints in High-Frequency Trading
problems.description: Capital markets firms face an increasingly difficult challenge in performing real-time risk monitoring within the ultra-low latency requirements of modern trading systems. The HFT market has grown to $7.147 billion in 2025, racing toward $28.96 billion by 2033, with AI-driven algorithmic trading accounting for 70% of US stock market volume. Modern trading systems compete at the nanosecond level, where being one microsecond behind competition means losing profitable opportunities. Traditional risk checks that take milliseconds are completely inadequate; they must be compressed into nanosecond-scale operations requiring pre-computed risk limits and real-time P&L calculations. Large sell-side banks handle millions of positions daily with streaming market data involving hundreds of thousands of updates per second. Risk systems must ingest this data firehose while computing exposures, P&L, VaR, and liquidity metrics on the fly. Traditional computing platforms suffer from non-deterministic latency, making consistent trading performance impossible. Regulatory requirements like SEC Rule 15c3-5, MiFID II RTS 6, and Basel III mandate near real-time detection of erroneous trades and risk limit breaches, adding compliance complexity to the technical challenge.

problems.title: Geopolitical Risk Quantification and Integration into Financial Risk Models
problems.description: Financial institutions struggle to effectively quantify and integrate geopolitical risks into their risk management frameworks, despite geopolitical risk being considered the most likely risk to materialize in 2025-2026. Unlike market or credit risk, geopolitical risks are inherently multi-faceted, non-quantifiable through traditional methods, and can spread quickly across supply chains, economies, and markets creating systemic effects that are difficult to predict. Financial institutions find geopolitical risks less well embedded in their risk management frameworks compared to sectors with more experience (such as oil and gas). The challenges include modeling the financial impacts of military conflicts, tariff structures, international diplomatic shifts, and trade rule changes. These events often have non-linear impacts with second and third-order effects that cascade through global markets. Traditional scenario analysis approaches fail to capture the full range of possible outcomes, and the interconnected nature of modern economies means that regional conflicts can have global financial implications. The lack of historical data for calibration and the uniqueness of each geopolitical event makes quantitative modeling extremely difficult.

barriers: Lack of historical data for calibration

problems.title: Cyber Risk in Capital Markets Trading Infrastructure
problems.description: Cyber risk continues to present significant and evolving challenges for capital markets institutions, with attacks increasing in sophistication and frequency through AI-powered methods. The financial stakes continue to rise, putting immense pressure on risk managers to prevent costly breaches and regulatory scrutiny. Trading infrastructure represents a high-value target due to the potential for immediate financial gain, market manipulation, and systemic disruption. Key challenges include protecting ultra-low-latency trading systems where security measures cannot add significant overhead, defending against AI-powered attacks that adapt in real-time, managing third-party and supply chain cyber risks, and maintaining resilience during coordinated attacks. The interconnected nature of capital markets means that a successful attack on one major institution could cascade across the financial system. Regulatory requirements continue to expand, with supervisors increasingly focused on operational resilience and cyber incident reporting. The shortage of cybersecurity professionals with capital markets expertise compounds the challenge.

problems.title: Regulatory Fragmentation in FRTB and Basel IV Cross-Border Implementation
problems.description: Capital markets firms operating across multiple jurisdictions face increasing challenges from regulatory fragmentation in the implementation of the Fundamental Review of the Trading Book (FRTB) and broader Basel IV requirements. While the Basel Committee has established global standards, national implementations vary significantly in timing, scope, and specific requirements. This creates operational complexity as firms must maintain multiple calculation engines, reporting systems, and compliance frameworks for different jurisdictions. The regulatory pressure points include increasing complexity with limited harmonization, ever-increasing focus on regulatory specifics rather than principles, and fragmented technology stacks that cannot scale effectively across asset classes and geographies. In Europe, the Basel Committee continues to articulate new ways to think about managing risk through evolving recommendations for IRRBB and ICAAP. The US has delayed implementation while the EU moves forward, creating competitive imbalances. Banks responding with incremental upgrades find this piecemeal approach insufficient for the scale of regulatory change required.

problems.title: Systemic Risk from Non-Bank Financial Intermediary Interconnectedness
problems.description: The rapid growth of non-bank financial intermediaries (NBFIs) - including hedge funds, private equity, money market funds, and other shadow banking entities - has created new channels for systemic risk transmission that traditional risk frameworks struggle to capture. NBFIs now account for over 50% of global financial assets, yet they operate with less regulatory oversight and transparency than traditional banks. The interconnectedness between NBFIs and the regulated banking sector creates hidden concentration risks and potential for rapid contagion during market stress. Key challenges include limited visibility into NBFI leverage and liquidity positions, procyclical behavior amplifying market volatility, maturity and liquidity mismatches, and inadequate margin and collateral frameworks. The 2022-2023 LDI crisis in UK pension funds and the 2021 Archegos collapse demonstrated how NBFI failures can rapidly transmit stress to the broader financial system. Regulators are increasingly focused on NBFI risks, but data gaps and jurisdictional limitations constrain effective supervision.

problems.title: Talent Retention and Human Capital Risk in Risk Management Functions
problems.description: Financial institutions face intensifying human capital risks within risk management functions, with talent retention emerging as a critical concern for 2026. The specialized skills required for modern risk management - including quantitative modeling, AI/ML expertise, climate risk analysis, and cyber risk - are in short supply, creating fierce competition for qualified professionals. Human capital risks reflect growing concerns about workforce stability and the failure to attract or retain top talent in risk roles. The problem is exacerbated by the rapid evolution of risk management requirements, meaning skills that were adequate a few years ago may now be insufficient. Key challenges include competition from technology firms offering higher compensation, aging workforce in traditional risk areas, difficulty training junior staff on complex systems, and knowledge concentration in key individuals. The loss of experienced risk professionals can leave institutions vulnerable during stress events when institutional knowledge is most critical.

problems.title: Stablecoin and Digital Asset Risk Management Framework Gaps
problems.description: The emergence of stablecoins and digital assets presents novel challenges for capital markets risk management, with 2026 identified as a pivotal year for addressing these risks. Stablecoins could herald a new era of money, presenting both challenges and opportunities for banks and payment companies. However, existing risk management frameworks were not designed to address the unique characteristics of digital assets, including 24/7 trading, smart contract risks, custody challenges, and the novel failure modes of algorithmic stablecoins. Financial institutions must develop strategies to assess the creditworthiness of stablecoin issuers, manage collateral that may include digital assets, understand the contagion risks from crypto market volatility, and comply with evolving regulations across jurisdictions. The opacity of stablecoin reserve compositions, the potential for de-pegging events, and the integration of digital assets with traditional finance create risks that existing VaR models and stress tests cannot adequately capture.

problems.title: Economic Uncertainty and Interest Rate Risk Model Inadequacy
problems.description: Financial institutions face persistent challenges in managing economic uncertainty and interest rate risk, driven by fluctuating interest rates, inflation, tariffs, and global instability. Traditional interest rate risk models, calibrated on historical data from periods of relative stability, have proven inadequate for the volatile rate environment experienced since 2022. The Basel Committee continues to articulate new requirements for managing interest rate risk in the banking book (IRRBB) and running the Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process (ICAAP), but institutions struggle to implement models that capture the current dynamics. Challenges include modeling the unprecedented pace of rate changes, understanding deposit behavior in a high-rate environment, capturing basis risks between different rate indices, and stress testing for scenarios without historical precedent. The combination of inflation uncertainty, central bank policy shifts, and geopolitical factors creates a multi-dimensional risk landscape that stress testing frameworks struggle to address. Institutions must adopt proactive risk management strategies, including enhanced scenario analysis, revenue diversification, and dynamic hedging, but many lack the technical capabilities to implement these effectively.
